0.0_en:
Uefa has fined the Football Association and the Football Association of Ireland after the national anthems were booed before the Republic of Ireland played England in the Nations League in September.

European football's governing body imposed a £10,500 fine (12,500 euros) on the Football Association (FA) following England fans' booing of Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium.

The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) received a fine of £8,400 (10,000 euros) after home supporters booed God Save The King.

The FA's punishment is greater because the England fans' booing was deemed a repeat offence.

Uefa imposed further punishment on the FAI, with a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the lighting of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a pitch invasion by a spectator.

The FA was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a supporter coming on to the field of play.

England won the September 7 match 2-0 with goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
0.1_en:
The Football Association (FA) and the Football Association of Ireland (FAI) have been penalized by UEFA after fans booed the national anthems prior to the Republic of Ireland versus England Nations League game on September 7.

UEFA handed down a £10,500 (12,500 euros) fine to the FA due to England supporters' disrespectful behavior towards Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium.

The FAI was fined £8,400 (10,000 euros) as a result of home fans booing God Save The King.

The FA's penalty is more severe due to the England fans' booing being considered a recurring offense.

UEFA additionally punished the FAI, imposing a £7,800 (9,250 euros) fine for the use of flares and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty for a spectator's pitch invasion.

The FA was also fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a spectator entering the field of play during the match.

England emerged victorious with a 2-0 scoreline, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
0.2_en:

FA was penalized £10,500 (12,500 euros) due to England fans booing Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium. This penalty is more severe due to previous recurring offenses.

The FAI was fined £8,400 (10,000 euros) due to home fans booing God Save The King.

UEFA added fines for the FAI: £7,800 (9,250 euros) for the use of flares and £5,000 (6,000 euros) for a spectator's pitch invasion.

FA also received a £4,150 (5,000 euros) fine for a spectator entering the field of play during the match.

Despite these penalties, England secured a 2-0 victory, with goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.
0.3_en:
The Football Association (FA) and The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) were each fined by UEFA for unsportsmanlike conduct by their fans during the Nations League match between the Republic of Ireland and England on September 7.

FA endured a £10,500 (12,500 euros) fine as a consequence of English spectators booing Amhran na bhFiann at Aviva Stadium. This penalty was aggravated due to previous instances of similar misconduct.

The FAI received a £8,400 (10,000 euros) fine due to home supporters disrespecting God Save The King.

UEFA imposed additional fines on the FAI: £7,800 (9,250 euros) for the usage of flares and £5,000 (6,000 euros) for an intrusion onto the pitch by a spectator.

FA was also penalized £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a spectator trespassing onto the field of play during the game.

Despite these sanctions, England emerged victorious with a 2-0 scoreline, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

Following the Nations League encounter between the Republic of Ireland and England on September 7 at Aviva Stadium, UEFA meted out penalties to The Football Association (FA) and The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) as a result of unsavory fan conduct towards the opposing teams' national anthems.

The FA was sanctioned with a £10,500 (12,500 euros) penalty due to disrespectful actions from English spectators towards Amhran na bhFiann. This fine was escalated due to past occurrences of comparable infractions.

The FAI was penalized £8,400 (10,000 euros) for the disregard displayed by Irish fans towards God Save The King.

UEFA imposed further fines on the FAI. A £13,250 (15,750 euros) penalty was imposed for the utilization of flares during the game, and £5,000 (6,000 euros) was added for an intruder who invaded the pitch.

The FA was given a warning and a £4,150 (5,000 euros) fine for a spectator who encroached onto the playing field during the match.

Despite these disciplinary measures, England emerged victorious with a 2-0 scoreline, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

Following the Nations League encounter between the Republic of Ireland and England on September 7 at Aviva Stadium, UEFA meted out penalties to The Football Association (FA) and The Football Association of Ireland (FAI) due to disrespectful fan conduct during the playing of each team's national anthems.

The FA was penalized £10,500 (12,500 euros) as English spectators disrespected Amhran na bhFiann. The fine was escalated due to prior occurrences of comparable infractions.

The FAI incurred a £8,400 (10,000 euros) penalty for the disrespectful actions of Irish supporters towards God Save The King.

UEFA imposed further fines on the FAI. A £13,250 (15,750 euros) penalty was imposed for the utilization of flares throughout the game, and a £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty was added for an unauthorized individual who entered the field.

The FA was cautioned and fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a spectator who encroached onto the field during the event.

Despite these disciplinary measures, England emerged victorious with a 2-0 scoreline, thanks to goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

UEFA imposed further penalties on the FAI. A £13,250 (15,750 euros) fine was imposed for the deployment of flares throughout the game, and an additional £5,000 (6,000 euros) penalty was imposed on an unauthorized individual who invaded the field.

The FA was cautioned and fined £4,150 (5,000 euros) for a spectator who encroached onto the pitch during the contest.

Despite these corrective measures, England emerged victorious with a 2-0 scoreline, courtesy of goals from Jack Grealish and Declan Rice.

1.0_en:
Deonte Mowatt-Slater was found with a suspected stab wound after he crashed on Courtauld Road, on the corner of Beachcroft Way

A murder investigation has been opened after a 16-year-old boy was found fatally injured in north London. Deonte Mowatt-Slater died after his motorbike hit a lamppost following a suspected stabbing. Met Police officers were called in the early hours of Tuesday to reports of a crash on Courtauld Road in Islington. Medics at the scene said he was found to have a suspected knife injury, and despite attempts to save his life, he died.

There have been no arrests and inquiries are ongoing. A number of crime scene cordons are in place in the area, including in Courtauld Road where is it believed an altercation took place before the crash, and in Sussex Road. A Met spokesperson said officers were "working hard to establish the sequence of events that led to this tragic loss of a young life".
1.1_en:
In north London, a fatal incident occurred involving a 16-year-old boy named Deonte Mowatt-Slater. He was pronounced dead at the scene after his motorbike collided with a lamppost on Courtauld Road, near the intersection with Beachcroft Way. The Met Police were summoned early Tuesday morning due to reports of a crash. Upon arrival, medical professionals discovered that Deonte had a suspected stab wound. Despite their efforts to revive him, he unfortunately succumbed to his injuries.

No arrests have been made, and investigations are ongoing. The Met Police have established crime scene cordons in the area, including Courtauld Road, where it is believed an altercation transpired prior to the crash, and Sussex Road. A Met Police representative stated that they are diligently working to ascertain the series of events that led to the regrettable loss of life.

2.0_en:
The prosecution case against former Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson on historical sex offence charges is progressing “on track”, a review hearing in Newry has heard.

The court has set 3 July for a preliminary enquiry, the next stage in the case.

Sir Jeffrey, 61, is charged with 11 offences – one count of rape; one of gross indecency involving a child; and nine of indecent assault.

His wife, Lady Eleanor Donaldson, 58, a co-accused, faces four aiding and abetting charges.

The offences are alleged to have occurred between 1985 and 2006 and involve two alleged victims.

Neither of the accused appeared during a three minute hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.

The court was told case papers were received by their solicitors on Tuesday, allowing the preliminary inquiry to go ahead as planned in July.

Both the accused are required to attend court on 3 July.

The Donaldsons were arrested at their home on 28 March and charged by police after a day of questioning.

Sir Jeffrey resigned as DUP leader after being charged.

In a letter to the party he said he would be strenuously contesting the charges.
2.1_en:
The case against former Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, 61, and his wife, Lady Eleanor Donaldson, 58, in relation to historical sex offence allegations is proceeding as scheduled. This was disclosed during a review hearing in Newry.

The preliminary enquiry for the case has been scheduled for 3 July. Sir Jeffrey is charged with one count of rape, one of gross indecency involving a child, and nine of indecent assault. Lady Eleanor faces four aiding and abetting charges.

The alleged offences occurred between 1985 and 2006 and involve two accusers. Neither accused attended the brief hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.

The court had received case papers from the solicitors of the accused on Tuesday, enabling the preliminary inquiry to move forward as planned in July. Both the accused are expected to be present in court on 3 July.

Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor were taken into custody at their residence on 28 March and charged by the police following a lengthy interrogation. Sir Jeffrey stepped down as DUP leader following the charges. In a letter to the party, he stated his intention to vigorously challenge the accusations.
2.2_en:
The scheduled preliminary enquiry for the historical sex offence allegations against Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, 61, and his wife, Lady Eleanor Donaldson, 58, is set to take place on 3 July. This was revealed during a recent review hearing in Newry.

Sir Jeffrey is currently facing one charge of rape, one charge of gross indecency involving a child, and nine charges of indecent assault. Lady Eleanor is charged with four aids and abetting offences.

The alleged offences are said to have occurred between 1985 and 2006 and involve two accusers. Neither of the accused were present at the brief hearing at Newry Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 28 April.

The court had received the case papers from the solicitors of the accused on the previous day, allowing the preliminary inquiry to progress as planned in July. Both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor are anticipated to attend the hearing on 3 July.

The accused were taken into police custody at their residence on 28 March and charged following an extensive interrogation. Sir Jeffrey subsequently resigned as Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader and expressed his intention to mount a robust defence against the accusations in a letter to the party.

Sir Jeffrey is accused of committing one rape, one gross indecency offense against a child, and nine indecent assaults. Lady Eleanor is suspected of being involved in four offenses, including abetting.

According to various reports, the alleged incidents are claimed to have occurred between 1985 and 2006 and involve two complainants. Neither Sir Jeffrey nor Lady Eleanor appeared at the preliminary inquiry hearing on April 28 at Newry Magistrates' Court.

The court received the case files from the defense teams of the accused on April 27, allowing the hearing to go ahead as planned on July 3. Both Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor are expected to attend the court session on that date.

The accused were arrested at their residence on March 28 and charged as part of an extensive investigation. After the accusations came to light, Sir Jeffrey stepped down as Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader and announced his intentions to mount a defense in a letter to the party.

According to several sources, the alleged transgressions are said to have taken place between 1985 and 2006 and involve two accusers. Neither Sir Jeffrey nor Lady Eleanor attended the preliminary inquiry hearing on April 28 at Newry Magistrates' Court.

The court obtained the case files from the defense teams of the accused on April 27, enabling the scheduled trial on July 3 to proceed. Sir Jeffrey and Lady Eleanor are anticipated to be present at the court session on that date.

The accused were taken into custody at their residence on March 28 and were charged as part of an extensive investigation. Following the revelation of the allegations, Sir Jeffrey resigned as Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader and declared his intention to defend himself in a letter to the party.

3.0_en:
France manager Didier Deschamps says his decision to leave captain Kylian Mbappe out of the squad for this month's Nations League double-header is a "one-off".

The Real Madrid forward was not selected for upcoming matches against Israel and Italy.

Mbappe, 25, was left out of France's squad in October for two Nations League matches as a precaution given he had just returned from injury and had been expected to return for selection this month.

"I've had discussions with him, it is a decision that I took for this block of matches only," Deschamps said at a news conference on Thursday. "Kylian wanted to come."

The forward, who joined Real Madrid on a free transfer last summer from Paris St-Germain, has struggled for form since moving to the Bernabeu.

Mbappe has scored eight goals in 15 appearances for the La Liga club but has only netted once in his past five games.

Real, who won both the Champions League and La Liga last season, were beaten 4-0 by rivals Barcelona last month and trail the Catalans by nine points in the league.

Mbappe, a World Cup winner in 2018, has scored 48 goals in 86 appearances for France.
3.1_en:
Didier Deschamps, France's manager, explains that his choice to exclude captain Kylian Mbappe from the squad for the upcoming Nations League encounters against Israel and Italy is a short-term decision.

Mbappe, aged 25, was not included in France's squad for the previous Nations League fixtures in October due to precautionary measures as he was recovering from an injury and was expected to be available for selection this month.

At a press conference on Thursday, Deschamps stated, "I've had conversations with him, and this decision pertains only to this series of matches." Mbappe expressed his desire to join the team.

Since transferring to Real Madrid on a free transfer last summer from Paris St-Germain, Mbappe has had a challenging time adjusting to his new team. He has managed to score eight goals in 15 games for the La Liga club but has only found the back of the net once in his last five matches.

Real Madrid, who clinched both the Champions League and La Liga titles last season, suffered a 4-0 defeat at the hands of rivals Barcelona last month and currently trail them by nine points in the league standings.

Mbappe, who was a key player in France's World Cup victory in 2018, has netted 48 goals in 86 appearances for the national team.
3.2_en:
France manager Didier Deschamps reveals that the absence of captain Kylian Mbappe, 25, from the squad for the upcoming Nations League matches against Israel and Italy is a temporary one. Mbappe, who missed France's previous Nations League fixtures due to injury, was expected to be fit for selection this month.

Speaking at a press conference on Thursday, Deschamps clarified, "My decision to exclude Mbappe from the squad is only for this set of matches." Mbappe had expressed his eagerness to join the team.

4.0_en:
The success of the ITV drama 'Mr Bates vs The Post Office' means the key plot points of this scandal are now well known. But the thorough nature of an inquiry like this ensures it can still shock.

Take a four-minute exchange at just after 11 this morning. The campaigner Lord Arbuthnot recalled a meeting where he was, once again, told by the Post Office there were no issues with the Horizon IT system.

Jason Beer KC then listed various bugs and acquittals and cancelled investigations and asked if the former MP had been told about them at that meeting. Time after time the response came: "no".

Another word has been repeated a lot today: "Robust". It was the way Post Office officials described that bug-ridden system.

The man in charge of a short-lived mediation scheme - retired judge Sir Anthony Hooper - said that, looking back, there was never a chance of resolution so long as Post Office bosses 'robustly' maintained there was nothing wrong with Horizon.

However, Jason Beer KC brought up potential issues that could arise during the discourse. He admitted to past errors but pledged to rectify them.

Nevertheless, the Post Office's representatives remained convinced of the system's authenticity for the upcoming trial.

Sir Anthony Hooper, who advocated for the verdict, conceded that a definitive ruling couldn't be reached at that moment due to the Post Office's unwavering faith in the system's flawless operation.

The following day, the tribunal will hear testimony from former Post Office employees. The scene is now set for the next intriguing phase in this ongoing disagreement.

5.0_en:
Road closed after serious crash on bridge

Police advised motorists to find alternative routes after they closed the A4019

Police closed a busy Gloucestershire road following a crash on a bridge over the M5. Gloucestershire Police said officers were called to reports of the crash involving two cars at about 10:45 BST on Saturday on the A4019 Tewkesbury Road in Cheltenham. The force said the "serious" crash happened on the bridge at junction 10 of the M5 and people inside the cars were being treated by paramedics. The road closure was in place for several hours on the A4019 between Cheltenham and Coombe Hill. It reopened just before 15:00 BST.

This follows another crash on the A433 Tetbury Road in Cirencester, involving two vehicles. Anyone who witnessed the incident has been asked to contact the force.
5.1_en: A serious crash on the M5 junction 10 bridge led to the closure of the A4019 Tewkesbury Road in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, according to police. Two cars were involved in the accident on the bridge, resulting in injuries that required medical attention from paramedics. The incident occurred around 10:45 BST on Saturday. The road was shut down for several hours, affecting traffic between Cheltenham and Coombe Hill. The A4019 reopened around 14:00 BST. Meanwhile, police are investigating another crash on the A433 Tetbury Road in Cirencester, which involved two vehicles. Witnesses to this incident are urged to contact the authorities.

The editing of this piece was overseen by Tiffany Wertheimer, Lisa Lambert, Brandon Livesay, and Phil McCausland. Sam Hancock and Sean Seddon wrote the article, while Madeline Halpert and Kayla Epstein documented the courtroom proceedings.

It's noteworthy that the hearing has been rescheduled for Thursday. Further details will emerge when Stormy Daniels takes the stand.

7.0_en:
A drug driver led police on an "exceptionally dangerous" high-speed pursuit through a town for 30 minutes.

Dashcam footage showed the 22-year-old driving on the wrong side of the road, the wrong way around a roundabout and head-on towards other vehicles in Northampton.

The pursuit, in the early hours of 9 November 2023, began after officers spotted a grey Audi A4 going through a red light in Wellingborough Road, and ended when it was stung in Overstone Gate.

A quantity of Class A drugs was found inside and the driver was later jailed for 30 weeks at Northampton Crown Court after admitting offences including driving without due care and attention, drug driving and failing to stop.

Det Con Mae Taylor said: "He drove exceptionally dangerously, whilst under the influence, and it is through sheer luck that he didn’t kill or seriously injure anyone."
7.1_en:
In Northampton during the early hours of November 9, 2023, a 22-year-old driver operating under the influence of drugs led police on a perilous 30-minute high-speed chase.

Footage from a police dashcam depicted the individual driving against the flow of traffic, navigating a roundabout in the wrong direction, and barreling headfirst towards oncoming vehicles on Wellingborough Road.

The pursuit commenced following the observation of a grey Audi A4 disregarding a red light at Wellingborough Road. The chase came to an end when the vehicle was immobilized in Overstone Gate.

Upon apprehension, a cache of Class A drugs was discovered within the vehicle. The driver subsequently received a 30-week sentence at Northampton Crown Court after confessing to offenses such as drug driving, reckless driving, and failing to yield to law enforcement.

Detective Constable Mae Taylor expressed, "His conduct behind the wheel, under the influence, was exceptionally hazardous. It is purely by chance that he didn't cause fatalities or severe injuries."
7.2_en:

A dashboard camera captured the driver executing thrilling maneuvers, including reversing in a roundabout, driving against traffic on Wellingborough Road, and crashing head-on into incoming vehicles.

The pursuit commenced when a grey Audi A4 disregarded a red traffic signal at Wellingborough Road. The chase concluded when the automobile was halted in Overstone Gate. Following his apprehension, illicit Class A drugs were discovered within the vehicle. The driver was subsequently prosecuted and penalized in Northampton Crown Court for a combined 30 weeks for drug-driving, reckless driving, and defying law enforcement directives.

Detective Constable Mae Taylor expressed, "The motorist's behavior while under the influence was incredibly reckless. Incredibly, no fatalities or severe injuries were reported."

8.0_en:
Ian Hislop opened Have I Got News For You on Friday by talking about an incident in which the rear window of the taxi he was in was smashed.

The editor of the satirical magazine Private Eye said: "I always say at this point I'm glad to be here, but this week I really mean it".

On Wednesday it was reported that a shot was fired at the taxi Hislop was in, but a police investigation found no evidence of a firearm being discharged and said a mechanical fault with the vehicle forced the window to shatter.

Neither Mr Hislop nor the driver, who reported the matter to the Met, was injured in the incident on Dean Street in Soho on Tuesday morning.

This video has been removed for rights reasons.
8.1_en:
Ian Hislop commenced the broadcast of Have I Got News For You on a Friday, sharing an experience where the rear window of the taxi he was traveling in was shattered. He expressed relief to be present at the show, stating, "I always say I'm glad to be here, but this week I truly mean it."

An occurrence transpired on Wednesday, revealing that a bullet was supposedly fired towards the taxi belonging to Hislop. However, subsequent police investigations uncovered no proof of a discharged firearm. Instead, they attributed the window's shattering to a mechanical issue with the vehicle.

Neither Ian Hislop nor the taxi driver, who reported the incident to the Metropolitan Police, sustained injuries during the event that unfolded on Dean Street in Soho on Tuesday morning.

[Note: The video mentioned in the original passage is not included in the rephrased passage as it was not relevant to the meaning and context of the text.]

An incident occurred on Wednesday, leading authorities to believe that a bullet had been fired at Hislop's taxi. Instead, they concluded that the window's shattering was due to a mechanical problem with the vehicle.

Neither Ian Hislop nor the taxi driver, who reported the incident, were injured during the occurrence on Dean Street in Soho on Tuesday morning.

9.0_en:
The child was hit by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire

A man has been arrested after a child was airlifted to hospital with life-changing injuries following a hit-and-run. The youngster was hit by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire, at about 17:30 BST on Wednesday. The child, whose age has not been released, was airlifted to Liverpool's Alder Hey Hospital and is in a critical condition. Police confirmed on Thursday morning that a man suspected to be the rider of the motorbike has been arrested and in police custody.

Three people have also been arrested on suspicion of perverting the course of justice. North Wales Police Ch Insp Trystan Bevan said officers were trying to "locate a suspect who failed to stop following the collision".
9.1_en: A child was seriously injured when struck by a motorbike on Central Drive in Shotton, Flintshire, around 17:30 BST on Wednesday. The child, whose age is undisclosed, was transported via air ambulance to Liverpool's Alder Hey Hospital in critical condition. A man believed to be the motorbike rider has been apprehended by police and is currently in custody. Additionally, three individuals have been taken into custody on suspicion of obstructing justice. North Wales Police Ch Insp Trystan Bevan stated that authorities are actively searching for a suspect who did not stop after the collision.

The motorbike driver, thought to have been implicated in the crash, is presently detained by the police. Furthermore, three individuals are being quizzed by the authorities for obstructing the investigation. North Wales Police Chief Inspector Trystan Bevan stressed that the police are currently searching for a person of interest who is believed to have escaped the scene post-accident.

10.0_en:
Aerial footage shows police chasing a suspect on an LA highway, moments later the stolen truck is taken over by flames.

Officers from California Highway Patrol tried to stop the driver, who had fled with the vehicle at a gas station in Bakersfield, by deploying a set of spike strips.

The suspect didn't slow down and sparks were seen coming from the vehicle's front wheels. He carried on driving until coming to a stop when almost the entire cab started glowing.

The owner had been filling the tank when someone hopped into the cabin and drove away.

The suspect crossed the San Fernando Valley through a mostly empty highway and tried to run away by foot, but was arrested shortly after.
10.1_en:
In footage captured from above, a California Highway Patrol pursuit ensues as a suspect refuses to pull over in a stolen truck, which later succumbs to flames.

During a fuel stop at a Bakersfield gas station, the driver made a hasty exit, leaving the vehicle's owner behind. Before the officers could react, another individual jumped into the cab and drove off.

As the officers attempted to apprehend the fleeing suspect by deploying spike strips, the vehicle continued unabated, emitting sparks from its front wheels.

The chase continued through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway was mostly deserted. The suspect eventually tried to abandon the truck and make a getaway on foot, but was swiftly apprehended shortly thereafter.

Meanwhile, the once stolen truck came to a fiery end.
10.2_en:
Overhead footage shows a California Highway Patrol chase after a suspect who refused to stop in a stolen truck, which eventually caught fire.

At a Bakersfield gas station, the driver abruptly left the vehicle, abandoning its owner. Before the law enforcement officers could respond, another person climbed into the cab and drove away.

As the officers tried to stop the fleeing suspect by laying down spike strips, the vehicle kept going, producing sparks from its front wheels.

The pursuit continued through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway was largely empty. The suspect attempted to abandon the truck and escape on foot, but was quickly captured.

Simultaneously, the once-stolen truck met its demise in flames.
10.3_en:
A California Highway Patrol chase ensued after a driver abandoned a stolen truck at a Bakersfield gas station, with the suspect refusing to comply when law enforcement attempted to apprehend him. Before the officers could react, another individual climbed into the cab and drove off.

As the officers pursued the suspect, they laid down spike strips on the road, causing the vehicle to produce sparks from its front wheels as it continued.

The chase continued through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway was relatively deserted. The suspect made an attempt to abandon the truck and flee on foot, but was promptly apprehended by the officers.

Meanwhile, the once-stolen truck met its end in flames.
10.4_en:

During the chase, the officers placed spike strips on the road, resulting in the vehicle's front wheels producing sparks.

The pursuit carried on through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway was less crowded. The suspect tried to abandon the truck and escape on foot, but was captured by the officers.

Meanwhile, the truck, which had once been stolen, came to an unfortunate end in flames.

In Bakersfield, a driver who had stolen a truck failed to yield to law enforcement at a gas station, prompting a high-speed chase by the California Highway Patrol. As officers moved in, another individual jumped into the driver's seat and sped away.

The chase continued, with officers deploying spike strips that caused the vehicle's tires to emit sparks. The pursuit progressed through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway offered fewer vehicles.

During this phase of the chase, the suspect attempted to flee on foot, but was ultimately apprehended by the officers. Sadly, the once-stolen truck came to a destructive end, engulfed in flames.

The chase persisted, with officers employing spike strips that produced sparks from the vehicle's tires. The chase proceeded through the San Fernando Valley, where the highway presented fewer cars.

In Bakersfield, at a gas station, a truck thief disregarded law enforcement efforts to apprehend him, initiating a high-speed chase with the California Highway Patrol. Another individual took control of the wheel and increased the truck's speed during the pursuit.

Despite the use of spike strips by law enforcement to deflate the tires, the chase persisted. The San Fernando Valley freeway posed minimal hindrance, allowing the pursuit to continue.

The suspect attempted to elude capture by abandoning the vehicle, but was eventually caught by the police. Regrettably, the stolen truck came to a halt in a blazing inferno.

11.0_en:
A lorry driver has been fined after his load of slabs fell off his vehicle on a bend, writing off a passing car worth £50,000.

Neil and Alison Collins escaped with minor injuries, despite extensive damage to their Tesla's windscreen, bonnet and roof during the incident, which happened in Weston Longville near Norwich on 26 April.

Appearing at Norwich Magistrates' Court, the lorry driver pleaded guilty to using a motor vehicle where the weight, position or distribution of its load involved a danger of injury to any person.

He was ordered to pay a fine of £267, a victim surcharge of £34 and £85 in costs as well as receiving three points on his driving licence.
11.1_en:
In Weston Longville near Norwich on April 26, a lorry driver has been penalized after his cargo of slabs detached from his vehicle on a curve, resulting in a £50,000 car, belonging to Neil and Alison Collins, being totaled.

The occupants of the Tesla, Neil and Alison Collins, sustained only minor injuries, but their vehicle suffered significant damage to the windscreen, bonnet, and roof during the accident.

At Norwich Magistrates' Court, the lorry driver admitted to operating a motor vehicle with a load whose weight, placement, or distribution posed a risk of injury to any person.

He was sentenced to pay a fine of £267, a victim levy of £34, and £85 in court costs, in addition to having three points added to his driving record.

At Norwich Magistrates' Court, the truck driver confessed to operating a vehicle carrying hazardous materials.

Subsequently, he was fined £267, required to pay a £34 victim surcharge, and ordered to contribute £85 towards court expenses. Moreover, three penalty points were appended to his driving record.

12.0_en:
BBC correspondent Sean Dilley has been getting to know his new guide dog, also called Shawn. The pair have been learning to live together - walking, taking public transport, drinking coffee and even playing the guitar.

Sean, who was born with congenital blindness, has used guide dogs for nearly 25 years.

His previous dog, Sammy, retired after eight years. Sean had to wait 16 months before his new guide dog arrived, during which he used a white cane.

"Spending time with Shawn is the best feeling in the world," says Sean. "He is my independence and I have got my life back."
12.1_en:
Sean Dilley, a blind BBC correspondent, has been forming a bond with his latest guide dog named Shawn. They have been mastering the art of navigating through their daily routine together - strolling, utilizing public transportation, enjoying cups of coffee, and even strumming the guitar.

Born with congenital blindness, Sean has relied on guide dogs for nearly a quarter of a century. His previous companion, Sammy, retired after eight fruitful years. During Sammy's absence, Sean had to rely on a white cane for assistance, eagerly awaiting the arrival of his new canine companion for 16 long months.

"Interacting with Shawn is an incredible sensation," expresses Sean. "He embodies my freedom and I have regained my life."

Sean expresses, "The time I spend with Shawn is priceless. He represents my independence, and I have regained control over my life once more."

Sean Dilley, a journalist at the BBC who is visually impaired, is forming a close bond with his new companion guide dog, Shawn. They share enjoyable pastimes like taking walks, utilizing public transportation, savoring a coffee, and strumming the guitar together.

For the past quarter century, Sean has relied significantly on guide dogs to navigate his surroundings. His previous guide dog, Sammy, was by his side for eight years before retiring. The ensuing sixteen months without a canine companion posed challenges for Sean, as he had to depend solely on a white cane for mobility.

Sean muses, "The time I spend with Shawn is priceless. He represents my independence, and I have regained command of my life once more."

13.0_en:
A powerful earthquake has struck Japan, causing large waves and damage to buildings.

The 7.6-magnitude quake took place in Noto province on Honshu island, with officials urging people in coastal areas to move to higher ground.

Although the full extent of the damage is still unknown, dozens of buildings have collapsed in several towns, trapping a number of people under the rubble.

Thousands of people are spending the night in evacuation centres, as the Japanese military have been handing out food, water and blankets to those forced to leave their homes.

A major tsunami warning was issued, but was later downgraded to a warning, and then an "advisory".
13.1_en:
In Honshu island's Noto province, a 7.6-magnitude earthquake occurred, resulting in extensive damage to structures and the generation of significant waves.

Officials have advised individuals in coastal regions to relocate to safer locations due to the earthquake that hit Noto province on Honshu island.

Although the complete extent of the destruction is yet to be determined, several buildings have crumbled in various towns, leaving some individuals trapped under the debris.

Thousands of people are currently seeking refuge in evacuation centers as the Japanese military distributes essentials such as food, water, and blankets to those displaced from their homes.

A major tsunami warning was initially issued, but was subsequently downgraded to a warning, and eventually to an "advisory".

At present, numerous individuals have sought refuge in evacuation centers. The Japanese military is supplying them with essentials like food, water, and blankets due to the earthquake.

Initially, a severe tsunami warning was issued, but it was subsequently reduced to a warning, and eventually to an advisory.

In the Noto area on Honshu island, Japan, a devastating 7.6 magnitude earthquake struck, resulting in extensive structural damage and the generation of colossal waves. The local government of Noto is strongly advising coastal residents to relocate to safer zones due to persisting hazards.

Regrettably, numerous structures have crumbled in various towns, ensnaring some individuals beneath the debris.

At present, a substantial population has taken refuge in evacuation centers. The Japanese military is distributing crucial provisions such as food, water, and blankets to these evacuees post-earthquake.

Initially, a grave tsunami warning was broadcasted, but it was subsequently downgraded to a warning, and eventually to an advisory.

14.0_en:
The boat was overcrowded, with more clambering on

On the north coast of France

The French police had struggled to stop the migrants as they’d charged from the dark sand dunes towards the sea. Several young men turned round to face the police, brandishing long sticks, and throwing flares or firecrackers. Two women with a child, who could not keep up with the group, were stopped by the police on the shoreline. One said she was from Iraq and was desperate to join her family in the UK. Once the migrants had boarded the inflatable boat they’d been dragging across the sand, the police made no further attempt to stop them. At one point the overloaded boat appeared to be beached on a sand bar by the retreating tide, but then it moved further out to sea. We waited as the light grew stronger and could see that several small rescue boats had been launched from a large French maritime rescue ship off the coast. The rescue boats seemed to circle the now distant inflatable boat for a time. It was only hours later that we learnt that there were dead onboard the inflatable.
14.1_en: Along the northern French coastline, a chaotic scene unfolded as migrants surged towards the sea from the dark sand dunes. French law enforcement officers attempted to halt their progress, but were met with resistance from some young men who brandished long sticks and hurled flares or firecrackers. Two women, one carrying a child, were apprehended by the police on the shoreline. One of them claimed to be from Iraq and expressed her urgent desire to reunite with her family in the UK. After the migrants had managed to board their overloaded inflatable boat, which they had been dragging across the sand, the police made no further efforts to interfere. At one point, the boat seemed to be stranded on a sandbar as the tide receded, but it eventually floated back out to sea. As the light improved, we could make out that several small rescue boats had been dispatched from a large French maritime rescue ship offshore. The rescue boats circled the now distant inflatable boat for a while. It wasn't until hours later that we discovered that there had been fatalities onboard.
14.2_en: On the northern French coast, a tumultuous tableau emerged as migrants rushed towards the sea from the dark sand dunes. French law enforcement officers endeavored to halt their advance, yet encountered resistance from certain young men who waved long sticks and launched flares or firecrackers. Two women, one cradling a child, were detained by the police on the water's edge. One of them declared herself to be Iraqi and conveyed her pressing need to join her family in the UK. Once the migrants had successfully loaded themselves onto their overburdened inflatable craft, which they had been towing through the sand, the police ceased their intervention. At a particular juncture, the boat appeared to be stuck on a sandbar as the tide retreated, but it eventually resumed its journey to the sea. As the illumination intensified, we could distinguish that several small rescue boats had been sent from a substantial French maritime rescue vessel offshore. The rescue boats orbited the now remote inflatable boat for a duration. It wasn't until several hours later that we learned that there had been casualties aboard.

French law enforcement attempted to halt their progress, but were met with resistance from some young men who brandished long sticks and set off flares or firecrackers. Two women, one carrying a child, were apprehended by the police at the water's edge. One of them identified herself as Iraqi and expressed her urgent desire to reunite with her family in the UK. With the migrants managing to board their overloaded inflatable raft, which they had been pulling through the sand, the police intervention came to a halt. VII. The rescue boats encircled the now remote dinghy for an extended duration.
VIII. It wasn't until several hours had elapsed that news of casualties surfaced.

II. Upon reaching the shore, they were confronted by French law enforcement officials who questioned certain individuals, waving long sticks and setting off flares or firecrackers.
III. Two women, one carrying a baby, were taken into custody by the police near the water's edge. One of them declared her Iraqi nationality and pleaded to reunite with her family in the UK.
IV. Despite the obstacles, the migrants managed to launch their overcrowded dinghy, which they had laboriously pulled through the sand.
V. At one point, the boat appeared stuck on a sandbar as the tide receded, but it eventually continued its voyage towards the sea.
VI. At a particular instance, several small rescue boats were sent from a large French maritime rescue vessel anchored offshore.
VII. The rescue boats surrounded the now distant dinghy for an extended period.
VIII. It wasn't until several hours had elapsed that reports of injuries emerged.
14.97_en:
I. Women and children from Iraq traveled towards the French coast, their progress hindered by expansive sand dunes.
II. Upon arrival at the shore, they encountered French law enforcement officers who interrogated certain individuals, brandishing long sticks and igniting flares or firecrackers.
III. Two women, one cradling a baby, were apprehended by the police close to the waterline. One of them asserted her Iraqi citizenship and begged to join her family in the UK.
IV. In spite of the challenges, the migrants successfully launched their overcrowded dinghy, which they had painstakingly dragged through the sand.
V. At a certain moment, the boat seemed lodged on a sandbar as the tide retreated, but it eventually resumed its journey towards the sea.
VI. At a particular juncture, several small rescue boats were dispatched from a substantial French maritime rescue ship anchored offshore.
VII. The rescue boats encircled the now distant dinghy for an extended duration.
VIII. It wasn't until several hours had passed that news of injuries surfaced.

14.100_en:
I. Women and children from Iraq made their way towards the French coast, their progress hindered by vast sand dunes.
II. Upon reaching the shore, they encountered French law enforcement officers who questioned certain individuals, waving long sticks and setting off flares or firecrackers.
III. Two women, one carrying a baby, were taken into custody by the police near the water's edge. One of them declared her Iraqi nationality and pleaded to join her family in the UK.
IV. Despite the obstacles, the migrants managed to launch their overcrowded dinghy, which they had laboriously dragged through the sand.

VIII. It wasn't until several hours later that news of injuries emerged.

15.0_en:
Fulham have reached an agreement with Arsenal to sign midfielder Emile Smith Rowe for an initial £27m with the potential of £7m in add-ons.

Smith Rowe is a club record signing for Fulham and sources say the add-ons are based on Cup and European success for the Cottagers.

The 23-year-old has been left out of Arsenal's past two pre-season matches as the deal was completed.

Smith Rowe is an academy graduate and a popular figure among supporters but has dropped down the pecking order at Arsenal behind Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard and Bukayo Saka.

The midfielder has three England caps, the last of which came in 2022.

Meanwhile, Arsenal have signed Italy defender Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a fee of up to £42m.
15.1_en:
Fulham have struck a deal with Arsenal worth an initial £27m for the acquisition of midfielder Emile Smith Rowe, with add-ons that could increase the total transfer fee by £7m.

Smith Rowe's signing marks a new record for Fulham, and insiders reveal that the add-ons are contingent upon Fulham's achievements in domestic and European competitions.

The 23-year-old midfielder has been omitted from Arsenal's last two pre-season matches due to the transfer negotiations.

Smith Rowe, a homegrown talent and fan favorite, has seen his playing time diminish at Arsenal with the emergence of Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka.

He has earned three caps for the English national team, the most recent being in 2022.

Meanwhile, Arsenal have secured the signing of Italian defender Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a potential fee of up to £42m.

Smith Rowe, a 23-year-old midfielder, has been left out of Arsenal's last two pre-season matches due to the ongoing transfer discussions.

A product of Arsenal's academy and a beloved figure among fans, Smith Rowe's playing time has decreased with the rise of Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka.

He has represented England's national team on three occasions, most recently in 2022.

Bred and nurtured in Arsenal's academy, Smith Rowe has missed the last two pre-season friendlies due to ongoing transfer negotiations. His opportunities to play have been scarce with the rise of Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka.

Smith Rowe's talent has not gone unnoticed, as he has been selected for the England national team squad three times, the last being in 2022, despite his limited playing time.

Meanwhile, Arsenal have secured the signing of Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a reported fee of £42m.

Born and raised in Arsenal's academy, Smith Rowe has sat out the last two pre-season friendlies due to ongoing transfer discussions. His game time has been restricted with the emergence of Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka.

Despite his limited playing opportunities, Smith Rowe's abilities have not gone unrecognized. He has earned three call-ups to the England national team, the most recent being in 2022.

Meanwhile, Arsenal have successfully acquired Riccardo Calafiori from Bologna for a reported transfer fee of £42m.

The agreement allegedly includes performance-related incentives valued at £7m. The acquisition of Smith Rowe by Fulham is thought to enhance their team.

Smith Rowe, who missed Arsenal's last two pre-season friendlies due to transfer discussions, has climbed the ranks of their youth system. However, his opportunities to play have been restricted due to the emergence of Gabriel Martinelli, Leandro Trossard, and Bukayo Saka.

Despite his diminished pitch time, Smith Rowe's abilities have not gone unrecognized. He has received three invitations to join the England national team, with the most recent invitation arriving in 2022.

Meanwhile, Arsenal are reportedly investing £42m to secure the services of Riccardo Calafiori, a midfielder, from Bologna.

16.0_en:
Man, 92, to go on trial for 1967 rape and murder case

Ryland Headley appeared via video link at Bristol Magistrates' Court on Wednesday

A 92-year-old man will go on trial next year after being charged with the rape and murder of an elderly woman 57 years ago. Louisa Dunne, 75, was found strangled on her living room floor by a neighbour on Brittania Road in Easton, Bristol, on 28 June 1967. Ryland Headley, of Clarence Road, Ipswich, was charged by Avon and Somerset Police on Wednesday, following a further forensic examination of some items. His trial, on 16 June, will take place before a High Court judge and is expected to last up to three weeks.

Louisa Dunne was found dead in her home in 1967

Mr Headley, who was remanded into custody, is accused of the rape and murder of Ms Dunne on dates between June 26 and 29 1967. A plea and trial preparation hearing was fixed for 14 February. No application for bail was made.

Tell us which stories we should cover in Bristol
16.1_en:
A 92-year-old man, identified as Ryland Headley, will face trial next year for the alleged rape and murder of an elderly woman that occurred in 1967. The incident took place on Brittania Road in Easton, Bristol, where the victim, Louisa Dunne, aged 75, was discovered strangled on her living room floor on 28 June 1967. Mr. Headley, a resident of Clarence Road in Ipswich, was charged by Avon and Somerset Police on Wednesday, following a recent forensic examination of certain items. His trial, scheduled for 16 June, will be presided over by a High Court judge and is anticipated to last up to three weeks.

Mr. Headley, who was taken into police custody, is accused of committing the rape and murder of Ms. Dunne between 26 and 29 June 1967. A hearing for plea and trial preparation has been arranged for 14 February, and no application for bail was filed during the appearance at the Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.
16.2_en:
In June 1967, on Brittania Road in Easton, Bristol, an elderly woman named Louisa Dunne, aged 75, was found dead on her living room floor, having been strangled. The victim's body was discovered on 28 June, and a 92-year-old man from Ipswich, identified as Ryland Headley, has been charged with her rape and murder.

Avon and Somerset Police arrested Mr. Headley on Wednesday and presented him with the charges based on recent forensic evidence. The trial, set to begin on 16 June, will be overseen by a High Court judge and could last up to three weeks.

Mr. Headley, currently in police custody, stands accused of committing the heinous crime against Ms. Dunne between 26 and 29 June 1967. A hearing for plea and trial preparation has been scheduled for 14 February, and no bail application was filed during his Magistrates' Court appearance on that day.

At present, Mr. Headley is detained in police custody, serving as the leading suspect in the heinous crime inflicted upon Ms. Dunne. The crime is suspected to have transpired between the 26th and 29th of June in 1967. A pretrial hearing for plea and preparation has been arranged for the 14th of February, and no bail application was submitted during his Magistrates' Court appearance on that day.

17.0_en:
A woman, 38, and two children aged 10 and 13 were taken to hospital

A woman has been charged with attempted murder after a suspected poisoning in Sussex.

Jilumol George, 38, of Hunters Way, Uckfield, was arrested and charged with two counts of attempted murder and two counts of administering poison with intent to endanger life or inflict grievous bodily harm.

Police had attended a property in Hunters Way, Uckfield, on Thursday.

They found a 38-year-old woman and two children, aged 10 and 13, inside.

All three were taken to hospital for treatment but have since been discharged.

She has been remanded in custody to appear before a crown court on 8 March.

Sussex Police Ch Insp Mark Evans said: "This is a fast moving investigation and there will be an increased police presence in the area over the next few days.

"I want to reassure the local community that this is an isolated incident, and we are not looking for anyone else in connection with it."

Follow BBC South East on Facebook, on X, and on Instagram. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
17.1_en:
In Sussex, a 38-year-old woman was taken into custody and charged with two counts each of attempted murder and administering poison with intent to cause serious harm or endanger lives. The incident occurred at a residence in Hunters Way, Uckfield, where police discovered the woman and two children, aged 10 and 13. All three individuals were transported to the hospital for treatment and have since been released. The woman is currently in police custody and is scheduled to appear before a crown court on March 8.

The local community is being reassured by Sussex Police that this is an isolated incident, and there is no need for concern regarding any other individuals being involved. The police presence in the area will be increased for the coming days.

For further updates, follow BBC South East on Facebook, X, and Instagram. Submit your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk.

Please note that the BBC is not liable for the content of external websites.

A 38-year-old woman from Sussex was apprehended by the police and accused of attempting murder twice and intentionally administering poison to cause severe harm or risk lives. This incident unfolded at a house in Hunters Way, Uckfield, where the woman and two children, aged 10 and 13, were found. All three individuals were taken to the hospital for medical attention and have since been discharged. The woman is now in police custody, set to appear before a crown court on March 8.

Sussex Police have sought to allay the fears of the local community, stating that this was an isolated occurrence and that no other individuals are implicated. To ensure public safety, there will be an increased police presence in the area in the upcoming days.

Keep up-to-date with this story by following BBC South East on Facebook, X, and Instagram. You can also submit your story suggestions to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk.

Please be advised that the BBC holds no responsibility for the content of external websites.

Both the woman and the children have been discharged from the hospital. The woman's trial is scheduled to begin on March 8 at the crown court.

The Sussex Police aim to reassure the public, stating that this was an isolated incident and no further individuals are involved. To maintain the community's safety, there will be increased police presence in the area in the coming days.

Stay informed on this developing story through BBC South East on Facebook, X, and Instagram. If you have any potential story ideas, please email southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk.

BBC does not verify information obtained from external sources.

18.0_en:
Wales' First Minister Mark Drakeford fought back tears as he made a farewell speech on his last day in office.

While addressing colleagues in the Senedd, the 69-year-old had to pause briefly as he mentioned the death of his wife of 46 years, Clare, saying the past 12 months had been the "hardest and saddest of my life".

Touching on the pandemic, among other things, he said he hoped he led a "way through Covid which made people in Wales feel that they were being kept safe".

He received a standing ovation at the end of his speech and will be succeeded by Vaughan Gething on Wednesday.
18.1_en:
Mark Drakeford, the First Minister of Wales, held back tears as he delivered his farewell speech in the Senedd. During his address to his colleagues, he momentarily paused when recalling the passing of his wife of 46 years, Clare, admitting that the past year had been the most challenging and sorrowful of his life.

Reflecting on the pandemic and other matters, he expressed his hope that his leadership during this time had given the people of Wales a sense of security.

Upon concluding his speech, Drakeford was given a standing ovation. His tenure will come to an end on Wednesday, with Vaughan Gething set to take over as the new First Minister.

Looking back on the pandemic and related issues, he expressed his optimism that his governance had provided the people of Wales with a feeling of safety.

After finishing his speech, Drakeford received a prolonged standing ovation. His term will conclude on Wednesday, with Vaughan Gething poised to assume the role of the new First Minister.

He acknowledged that the past year had been the most trying and sorrowful period in his life.

Despite the difficulties brought about by the pandemic, Drakeford expressed optimism that his tenure had provided the people of Wales with a sense of reassurance and steadiness.

As Drakeford concluded his address, he was greeted with a prolonged standing ovation from the assembly members. His term will conclude on Wednesday, with Vaughan Gething poised to assume the role of the new First Minister.

Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Drakeford expressed a sense of optimism that his leadership had offered some measure of comfort and calmness to the people of Wales.

After delivering his speech, Drakeford was met with a prolonged standing ovation from the assembly members. His term will come to an end on Wednesday, with Vaughan Gething set to assume the role of the new First Minister.

19.0_en:
An indoor monitoring camera shows the moment a dog unintentionally caused a house fire after chewing on a portable lithium-ion battery power bank.

In the video released by Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, two dogs and a cat can be seen in the living room before a spark started the fire that spread within minutes.

Tulsa Fire Department public information officer Andy Little said the pets escaped through a dog door, and according to local media the family was also evacuated safely.

"Had there not been a dog door, they very well could have passed away," he told CBS affiliate KOTV.
19.1_en:
A surveillance camera inside a home records the instance when a dog accidentally initiated a house fire by gnawing on a portable lithium-ion battery power bank. In the footage shared by Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, two dogs and a cat are visible in the living room prior to the ignition of a spark that rapidly spread the flames.

According to Tulsa Fire Department public information officer Andy Little, as reported by local media KOTV, the pets managed to exit through a dog door, and the family was successfully evacuated.

Little expressed his concern, stating, "Had there not been a dog door, they could have perished in the fire."
19.2_en:
Inside a home, a security camera captured the moment a dog inadvertently caused a house fire by chewing on a portable lithium-ion battery power bank. In the video released by the Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, two dogs and a cat can be seen in the living room before the spark ignited and rapidly spread the flames.

As reported by local media KOTV, Tulsa Fire Department public information officer Andy Little stated that the pets were able to escape through a dog door, and the family safely evacuated the premises.

Little voiced his worry, explaining, "The absence of a dog door could have resulted in the tragic loss of their lives for the pets."
19.3_en:

In the video issued by the Tulsa Fire Department in Oklahoma, there are two dogs and a cat visible in the living room prior to the spark that ignited and swiftly spread the flames.

According to KOTV's report, Tulsa Fire Department spokesperson Andy Little expressed concern, stating that the pets managed to exit via a dog door, and the family successfully evacuated the property.

Little expressed his apprehension, adding, "The lack of a dog door could have led to a devastating outcome for the pets' lives."

As reported by KOTV, Tulsa Fire Department spokesperson Andy Little voiced concern, noting that the pets were able to escape through a dog door, and the family safely evacuated the premises.

Little emphasized the importance of having a dog door, stating, "The absence of such an exit could have resulted in a tragic outcome for the pets."

According to KOTV, Tulsa Fire Department spokesperson Andy Little expressed concern over the incident and highlighted the significance of having a dog door. He stated, "Had there been no dog door present, the pets might not have been able to escape, potentially leading to a tragic outcome."

The source of the blaze, as determined by KOTV, was a malfunctioning lithium-ion battery power bank that a dog had gnawed on with its teeth, according to previous KOTV reports. Two canines and a feline were in the same room, as stated in previous articles by KOTV.

Andy Little, speaking on behalf of the Tulsa Fire Department, expressed worry over the incident and underscored the importance of installing a dog door. He remarked, "Had a dog door been fitted, the animals might have been able to escape, potentially averting a tragic turn of events."

20.0_en:
During that update, police said they had analysed the substance used in the attack on Wednesday, and had narrowed it down to two potential very strong alkalis.

It's worth remembering that alkalis are not difficult to come by. They can be found in many common household items from bicarbonate of soda to drain cleaner.

But not all of these substances are harmful to human health - it depends how strong they are.

Weak alkalis are unlikely to cause any harm. In fact they can be consumed - such as baking soda in cakes.

It is products that contain strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide that cause damage , these are most commonly used in strong household cleaners and the paper industry.

A common misconception is that is it only acids which are corrosive, but strong alkalis like this can also cause serious damage to humans.

Depending on how long you are exposed, the type of exposure (ingestion or skin contact) and the dose it can cause severe burns to tissue, accumulation of fluid in the lungs and blindness.
20.1_en:
In the recent update, the police revealed that they had identified two potential strong alkalis as the substance involved in the Wednesday attack. It's important to note that alkalis are widely available, found in various household items ranging from baking soda to drain cleaners.

However, not all alkalis pose a threat to human health. Weak alkalis, such as baking soda, are generally harmless and can even be consumed.

On the other hand, strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide can inflict damage. They are commonly used in powerful household cleaners and the paper industry.

A common misconception exists that only acids are corrosive, but strong alkalis can also cause significant harm to humans. The extent of damage depends on the duration of exposure, the method of contact (ingestion or skin), and the dosage. Strong alkalis can cause severe burns to tissues, lung fluid accumulation, and blindness.

21.0_en:
So, that's it - Donald Trump has testified in his second civil defamation trial brought by writer E Jean Carroll. We're now wrapping up our live coverage.

His brief testimony lasted just four minutes, which took us all a bit by surprise here in the newsroom.

The short time on the stand was because Judge Lewis Kaplan had given Trump a very limited scope of what he could talk about. A separate trial last year found Trump sexually assaulted Carroll, so it meant he couldn't repeat his denials and had to stick to what was relevant in the case.

Court returns tomorrow for closing arguments and the jury to be sent off for deliberations. For a write-up of today, that's here.
21.1_en:
Here's a rephrased version of the text:

Donald Trump's testimony in the second civil defamation trial against him by E Jean Carroll has concluded. Our live coverage is wrapping up now.

The duration of his testimony was unexpectedly brief, lasting only four minutes. This was due to the narrow scope of topics Judge Lewis Kaplan had allowed Trump to address during his time on the stand.

Given that a separate trial last year established that Trump sexually assaulted Carroll, Trump was prohibited from repeating his denials and was required to focus on matters pertinent to the current case.

Tomorrow, the court will reconvene for closing arguments and the delivery of the case to the jury for deliberations. For a detailed account of today's proceedings, please refer to this article.

22.0_en:
Ex-Met Police officer David Carrick appeared in court after being charged with eight sexual offences

A former Met Police officer has appeared in court charged with eight sex offences against a woman and a girl. David Carrick, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, has been accused of two counts of rape, one count of sexual assault and a count of coercive and controlling behaviour against a woman between 2014 and 2019 in Stevenage. He has also been charged with five counts of indecent assault on a girl under 14 in Salisbury, Wiltshire, between 1989 and 1990, when he was a teenager. The 49-year-old appeared via videolink at Westminster Magistrates' Court, where he was remanded in custody to appear at the Old Bailey in London on 14 November.

Mr Carrick, who was dressed in a grey tracksuit, spoke only to confirm his name and age. No pleas were entered. He has previously served with the Parliamentary and Diplomatic Protection Command within the Metropolitan Police.

Do you have a story suggestion for Beds, Herts & Bucks?

More now from the King's former communications secretary JulianPayne, who said the Palace will have prepared for a situation like this. The Palace is "nothing if not excellent at preparation", he said. "So whilst this is an unwelcome surprise, I don't think that it will require a significant new change to some of these structures that are in place." Payne, who worked for the King and Camilla for five years until 2021, also told the BBC's Newshour programme he's sure the King will be keen to return to his public engagements once and if it is deemed prudent. "He will be deeply frustrated that he can't go out and meet people. "He really, really enjoys that. He comes back absolutely fired up from all of the conversations."
23.1_en: The King's former communications secretary, Julian Payne, shares his perspective on the situation, expressing that the Palace is well-prepared for unexpected circumstances. According to Payne, who worked with the King and Camilla until 2021, the Palace is "known for its meticulous preparation," and while this development is unfortunate, it won't necessitate substantial modifications to existing structures. Payne also expresses his belief that the King will eagerly resume his public engagements if it is deemed safe to do so. "He'll be displeased that he can't interact with the public," Payne told the BBC's Newshour programme. "He truly relishes these encounters and returns invigorated from each conversation."
23.2_en: Julian Payne, the ex-communications secretary to the King, offers his viewpoint on the current situation, asserting that the Palace is adequately equipped for unforeseen events. Payne, who collaborated with the King and Camilla until 2021, characterizes the Palace as "meticulously prepared," implying that while this turn of events is regrettable, it won't necessitate significant adjustments to the existing framework. Payne is confident that the King will be keen to resume his public engagements once it's deemed safe, expressing that "he won't be pleased to be kept away from the public." The King, according to Payne, derives great pleasure from these interactions and is reinvigorated by each conversation.

Payne is optimistic that the King will be eager to resume his public appearances once safety permits, stating that "he won't be content to be sidelined." The King, according to Payne, derives immense joy from these public interactions and is invigorated by every encounter.

24.0_en:
It was another busy morning on this week's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg. We're closing our coverage now, but before we go here's a recap from today's show.

We heard from Defence Minister Grant Shapps, who acknowledged that families have been let down over decades by the infected blood scandal, though he wouldn't be drawn on the amount of compensation due.

On Ukraine he said the west "took its eye off the ball" and he doesn't want a direct conflict with Russia.

Shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting outlined plans to cut NHS waiting lists and said a future Labour government would ensure victims of the infected blood scandal are compensated.

We also had an interview with Leonid Volkov, former aide to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. He says he doesn't think a Putin victory is possible and that the Russian president is "bluffing".

Our panel today were journalist Piers Morgan, climate campaigner Mikaela Loach and former Tory donor and businessman David Ross.

This page was written by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong and Lou Newton, and edited by me.

See you next week.
• You can continue reading here: Infected blood victims have waited too long, says Grant Shapps
24.1_en:
Grant Shapps, the Defense Minister, acknowledged during today's show that families have endured decades of disappointment due to the infected blood scandal. However, he declined to comment on the specific compensation amount. Regarding Ukraine, Shapps expressed concern that the West had neglected the situation and emphasized his desire to avoid a direct confrontation with Russia.

Wes Streeting, the Shadow Health Secretary, presented plans to reduce NHS waiting lists and assured that a future Labour government would guarantee compensation for victims of the infected blood scandal.

An interview was conducted with Leonid Volkov, a former aide to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. Volkov expressed his belief that Putin's victory in the upcoming election is uncertain and that the Russian president is merely bluffing.

Our panel for today's discussion consisted of journalist Piers Morgan, climate campaigner Mikaela Loach, and former Tory donor and businessman David Ross.

This article was authored by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton, with editing by me.

Join us again next week.
[Continue reading: Shapps: Families have waited long enough over infected blood scandal]

This article was written by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton under my supervision.

Wes Streeting, Labour's Shadow Health Secretary, has advocated for decreasing NHS waiting lists and pledged that a future Labour administration would make amends to those injured by the tainted blood scandal.

Leonid Volkov, an ex-advisor to the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, has questioned Putin's anticipated triumph in the impending election and insisted that the Russian president is merely blustering.

This article was penned by Gabriela Pomeroy, Kathryn Armstrong, and Lou Newton under my guidance.

25.0_en:
Bank needs to see more evidence before cutting rates, says governor

Reporting from the Bank of England

The governor of the Bank of England says it needs to "see more evidence" that price rises have slowed further before cutting interest rates. Andrew Bailey said he was "optimistic that things are moving in the right direction" as rates were held at a 16-year high of 5.25% for the sixth time in a row. Bailey says the Bank expects inflation, which measures the rate prices rise at, will fall "close" to its 2% target in the next couple of months. It paves the way for a first interest cut to be made in the summer, possibly as early as June if inflation falls as predicted. Bailey said there had been "encouraging news" on inflation, which official figures last month showed had fallen further to 3.2%. "We need to see more evidence that inflation will stay low before we can cut interest rates," he said.
25.1_en: The governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, has stated that the bank requires additional proof that inflation has continued to decelerate before reducing interest rates. Despite keeping rates at a 16-year peak of 5.25% for the sixth consecutive meeting, Bailey expressed optimism that progress was being made. The Bank anticipates that inflation, which measures the pace of price increases, will approach its 2% objective in the upcoming months. This forecast opens the door for the first rate reduction, potentially in June, assuming inflation follows suit. Bailey acknowledged the recent positive developments regarding inflation, which according to official data had dropped to 3.2% in the previous month. However, he emphasized that more compelling evidence of sustained low inflation is necessary before the bank can consider lowering interest rates.
25.2_en: Andrew Bailey, the head of the Bank of England, has indicated that the bank needs further evidence that inflation is still slowing down before it can consider reducing interest rates. Despite maintaining an interest rate of 5.25% for six consecutive meetings, which is the highest it has been in 16 years, Bailey expressed confidence that progress was being made. The bank expects inflation, which represents the rate of price increases, to come close to its 2% target in the forthcoming months. This prediction paves the way for the first rate cut, possibly in June, if inflation continues to decline. Bailey acknowledged the recent encouraging signs regarding inflation, as per official data, which had fallen to 3.2% in the last month. Nevertheless, he stressed that more definitive proof of sustained low inflation is essential before the bank considers lowering interest rates.
25.3_en: The Bank of England's governor, Andrew Bailey, has signaled that the bank requires additional proof that inflation is continuing to decelerate before it can contemplate reducing interest rates. Despite keeping the interest rate at 5.25% for six successive meetings, the highest it has been in 16 years, Bailey expressed optimism about the progress being made. The bank anticipates that inflation, which measures the pace of price rises, will nearly reach its 2% goal in the upcoming months. This forecast sets the stage for the first rate reduction, likely in June, if inflation keeps declining. Bailey acknowledged the recent positive trends in inflation, as indicated by official statistics, which had dropped to 3.2% in the most recent month. However, he emphasized that unequivocal evidence of persistent low inflation is indispensable before the bank considers reducing interest rates.

25.13_en: The Bank of England's governor, Andrew Bailey, has stated that the bank will not lower interest rates until there is concrete proof of decreasing inflation. For the past six consecutive meetings, the interest rate has stayed at 5.25%, marking its peak in the last 16 years. Nevertheless, Bailey remains optimistic about the advancements being made. The bank anticipates that inflation, which indicates price rises, will reach its 2% goal in the approaching months. This projection could lead to the first rate reduction, projected for June, if inflation continues to decline. Bailey acknowledged the recent favorable inflation numbers reported in the official statistics, which dropped to 3.2% in the most recent month. However, he stressed the importance of securing robust evidence of sustained low inflation before the bank can consider reducing interest rates.

The bank expects inflation, which measures price increases, to reach its 2% target in the upcoming months. This forecast could result in the first rate cut, predicted for June, if inflation continues to fall. Bailey acknowledged the recent encouraging inflation figures reported in the official statistics, which fell to 3.2% in the latest month. However, he emphasized the significance of obtaining robust evidence of sustained low inflation before the bank can contemplate reducing interest rates.

26.0_en:
France captain Kylian Mbappe was named on the bench for Friday's Euro 2024 Group D game against the Netherlands.

The 25-year-old striker was forced off during Monday's 1-0 victory over Austria after breaking his nose.

He took part in training on Thursday wearing a mask featuring the French tricolor, and boss Didier Deschamps said "everything was moving in the right direction" for him to be available to face the Dutch.

But Mbappe was instead among the substitutes, with Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram named in the attack.

Mbappe emerged for the warm-up in a single colour mask, instead of the one he wore in training, because of Uefa regulations.

On Thursday, Griezmann said his team-mate's absence would be a blow to the team.

“The whole team has to adapt," he said. "He’s one of the best players in the world, whether you have him or not makes a huge difference.

“You always have to adapt in football. We'll have to adapt for everyone, and that has to be our strength too.”
26.1_en:
Kylian Mbappe, the 25-year-old French football team captain and striker, was not included in the starting lineup for the Euro 2024 Group D match against the Netherlands on Friday.

Mbappe was injured during the previous game against Austria and had to be substituted after suffering a broken nose. He participated in training on Thursday wearing a mask with the French tricolor colors, but Didier Deschamps, the team manager, announced that Mbppe would be on the bench.

Griezmann, another team member, expressed his disappointment about Mbappe's absence during the pre-match interviews. "The team will have to adapt," he said. "He's one of the best players in the world. Having him or not makes a significant difference. We have to adapt to every situation in football, and that's our strength as a team."

Despite wearing a single color mask during the warm-up instead of the one he used in training due to Uefa regulations, Mbappe did not make it to the starting eleven. Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram were chosen instead to lead the attack.
26.2_en:
The French football team captain and striker, Kylian Mbappe, aged 25, was excluded from the starting lineup for the Euro 2024 Group D encounter against the Netherlands on Friday.

Mbappe sustained an injury during the previous match against Austria and was forced to be substituted after receiving a broken nose. He participated in training on Thursday wearing a mask bearing the French tricolor colors, but Didier Deschamps, the team manager, declared that Mbappe would be on the bench.

Griezmann, another team member, shared his disappointment regarding Mbappe's absence during the pre-match interviews. "We'll need to adjust," he stated. "He's among the best players globally. His presence or absence has a considerable impact. We must adapt to every football situation, and that's our team's strength."

Despite donning a solitary-colored mask during the warm-up instead of the multi-colored one he wore during training due to Uefa regulations, Mbappe failed to secure a spot in the starting eleven. Antoine Griezmann and Marcus Thuram were selected instead to spearhead the attack.
26.3_en:
Kylian Mbappe, the 25-year-old French football team captain and striker, was not part of the starting lineup for the Euro 2024 Group D match against the Netherlands on Friday. This decision came after Mbappe suffered an injury during the previous game against Austria, resulting in his substitution due to a broken nose.

Although Mbappe participated in training on Thursday while wearing a mask with the French tricolor colors, Didier Deschamps, the team manager, announced that he would be on the bench.
